We see that with one thread, so when thereâ€™s no contention, it takes about 10 nanoseconds. This about 10 times as much as a regular operation.In the contended case, when we have 12 threads, it takes about 12 times as much, which is exactly what weâ€™d expect, because these atomic operations effectively serialize our threads.

è‡ªæ—‹é”ç¼ºç‚¹ï¼šcpuä¸€ç›´åœ¨å¿™ã€‚
æ”¹è¿›ï¼šé”å”¤é†’æœºåˆ¶
ä½†æ˜¯é”å”¤é†’æœºåˆ¶çš„æ•ˆç‡å¾ˆä½ï¼š
Our question again is, this is nice and all, but what is this upgrade going to cost us? We measure it, here is our microbenchmark. This is again in C, weâ€™re measuring the cost of a lock-unlock pair for a pthread Mutex. We see that in the uncontended case with one thread - again, itâ€™s about 10 nanoseconds, which is the cost of an atomic compare-and-swap, which is what weâ€™d expect, itâ€™s that atomic compare-and-swap that succeeded. In the contended case though, with 12 threads, the cost goes up to one microsecond, and this comes from the context switching cost, from that syscall, from switching into the kernel from the waiting, thatâ€™s why it goes up to a whole microsecond.

è§£å†³æ–¹æ³•ï¼šæŠ˜ä¸­
This insight, this tradeoff is captured in hybrid futexes. The way hybrid futexes work is, the thread does that compare and swap, if it fails, it first spins a small fixed number of times, and if it still doesnâ€™t get flagged, only then is the thread suspended. These hybrid futexes are pretty clever, and this is a variant of the pthread Mutex, uses the hybrid futex. Go has an internal futex implementation, and this is a hybrid futex.

At this point, weâ€™ve evolved from spinlocks to futexes to hybrid futexes.

release

å‡½æ•°å®šä¹‰ï¼š
pointer release() noexcept; (since C++11)

Releases the ownership of the managed object if any. get() returns nullptr after the call.
The caller is responsible for deleting the object.

è¯´æ˜ï¼šæ²¡æœ‰è¾“å…¥å‚æ•°ï¼Œè¿”å›å½“å‰unique_ptræŒ‡å‘çš„å¯¹è±¡

#include
#include
#include

struct Foo {
Foo() { std::cout << â€œFoo\nâ€; }
Foo() { std::cout << â€œFoo\nâ€; }
};

int main()
{
std::cout << â€œCreating new Fooâ€¦\nâ€;
std::unique_ptr up(new Foo());

std::cout << "About to release Foo...\n";
Foo* fp = up.release();

assert (up.get() == nullptr);
assert (up == nullptr);

std::cout << "Foo is no longer owned by unique_ptr...\n";

// delete fp;

Foo fp1 = Foo();
std::unique_ptr<Foo> up1(&fp1);
up1.release();
std::cout << "After call release" << std::endl;

}

entry.title: tasksetçš„ä½¿ç”¨
entry.content:
taskset (util-linux-ng 2.17.2)
usage: taskset [options] [mask | cpu-list] [pid | cmd [argsâ€¦]]
set or get the affinity of a process

-p, â€“pid operate on existing given pid
-c, â€“cpu-list display and specify cpus in list format
-h, â€“help display this help
-V, â€“version output version information

The default behavior is to run a new command:
taskset 03 sshd -b 1024
You can retrieve the mask of an existing task:
taskset -p 700
Or set it:
taskset -p 03 700
List format uses a comma-separated list instead of a mask:
taskset -pc 0,3,7-11 700
Ranges in list format can take a stride argument:
e.g. 0-31:2 is equivalent to mask 0x55555555

ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼štaskset -cp 0,3 9726

entry.title: dpdk demo
dpdkæ— é”é˜Ÿåˆ—
entry.content:
ç”Ÿäº§è€…æ¶ˆè´¹è€…æ¨¡å‹

  • The Ring Manager is a fixed-size queue, implemented as a table of
  • pointers. Head and tail pointers are modified atomically, allowing
  • concurrent access to it. It has the following features:
    • FIFO (First In First Out)
    • Maximum size is fixed; the pointers are stored in a table.
    • Lockless implementation.
    • Multi- or single-consumer dequeue.
    • Multi- or single-producer enqueue.
    • Bulk dequeue.
    • Bulk enqueue.
    • Ability to select different sync modes for producer/consumer.
    • Dequeue start/finish (depending on consumer sync modes).
    • Enqueue start/finish (depending on producer sync mode).
  • Note: the ring implementation is not preemptible. Refer to Programmerâ€™s
  • guide/Environment Abstraction Layer/Multiple pthread/Known Issues/rte_ring
  • for more information.
